articles.title: NJ Transit, Amtrak riders in for a month of disruptions for Portal Bridge transition
articles.excerpt: Amtrak and NJ Transit are bracing customers for a month of potentially difficult commutes with construction that will upend normal commuter schedules. Starting Sunday, Amtrak will begin work to transfer or “cut over” rail traffic from one track that crosses the 115-year-old Portal Bridge over the Hackensack River, to a track that crosses over the newly constructed Portal North Bridge. The work will require around 40,000 hours of work, with two shifts of around 70 to 90 workers a day.

articles.title: NJ Transit Major Service Update: Portal North Bridge Cutover • Millburn Township, NJ
articles.excerpt: Amtrak will perform critical construction to transfer, or “cut over,” rail operations from the existing Portal Bridge to the new Portal North Bridge over the Hackensack River. This work will require temporary but significant service changes starting Sunday, February 15 and last approximately four weeks. A major milestone in the Gateway Program, the work is essential to advancing long-term...

articles.title: Amtrak, NJ Transit major service cuts begin Sunday for Portal Bridge work
articles.excerpt: The buzz among Jersey commuters is Sunday’s start of a 53% NJ Transit rail service reduction as Amtrak begins the needed work to open the first track of the new $2.3 billion Portal North Bridge. The process, known as a cutover, will take a month to complete and take a bite out of every rail line’s schedule except the Atlantic City line. The work to switch one track from the old to the new bridge...

articles.title: The Big Switch: NJ TRANSIT and Amtrak Announce Month-Long Portal Bridge Service Changes
articles.excerpt: NJ Transit and Amtrak have announced coordinated service modifications for the Portal Bridge cutover. The changes, spanning approximately one month beginning February 15, will temporarily reduce rail service as Amtrak transfers operations to the new Portal North Bridge over the Hackensack River.

articles.title: Portal North Bridge cutover to disrupt NJ Transit service
articles.excerpt: NJ Transit and Amtrak riders face a month of significant service reductions beginning February 15 as crews work to connect the new Portal North Bridge to the Northeast Corridor. The cutover represents a critical milestone in the $2.3 billion Gateway Program project.

articles.title: NJ Transit To Reduce Service to New York Penn Station Through March 15
articles.excerpt: NJ Transit will reduce service to New York Penn Station through March 15 as part of the Portal North Bridge cutover. Montclair-Boonton Line riders face the biggest changes, with all weekday trains diverted to Hoboken Terminal.

articles.title: What the Portal Bridge cutover means for NJ Transit, Amtrak commuters
articles.excerpt: Starting February 13, Amtrak will initiate the first phase of transferring rail service from the century-old Portal Bridge to the newly constructed Portal North Bridge. All rail lines except the Atlantic City Rail Line will face temporary service adjustments beginning Sunday, February 15, lasting approximately four weeks. NJ Transit CEO Kris Kolluri noted that when the existing bridge gets stuck opening for marine traffic, manual intervention is sometimes required.

articles.title: Portal Bridge 'cutover' project to impact NJ Transit services. Here's what it means for you.
articles.author: Matt Trapani and Lauren Due
articles.excerpt: Amtrak will commence operations on February 15 to shift train traffic from the current Portal Bridge to the newly constructed Portal North Bridge spanning the Hackensack River. Single-track train operations will be the only option available between Newark and Secaucus during the roughly one-month transfer period. All Midtown Direct service will be redirected to Hoboken, with PATH cross-honoring and enhanced ferry service through New York Waterway during peak commute periods.

articles.title: NJ Transit alters schedules for Portal Bridge work
articles.author: Greg Mocker
articles.excerpt: Final construction of the new Portal Bridge requires a month of service changes for commuters. NJ Transit rail lines and Amtrak will be disrupted for 4 weeks as crews work to connect the new Portal North Bridge to the Northeast Corridor.

articles.title: PATH Riders Advised to Prepare for Delays from February 15th - March 15th
articles.excerpt: PATH riders in Hoboken and Jersey City should prepare for increased crowding and potential delays as thousands of NJ Transit riders are diverted to Hoboken Terminal during the Portal Bridge cutover. The Hoboken-to-33rd Street line will absorb most of the additional passenger load.

articles.title: 4 weeks of hell start Sunday: What to know as NJ Transit cuts 50% of trains
articles.author: Dan Alexander
articles.excerpt: NJ Transit will implement a significant service cut beginning February 15 for four weeks, affecting roughly half of all rail service into New York as crews transition signals and overhead wires to the new Portal North Bridge. Engineering teams will require 40,000 man-hours to complete the switchover, operating across two shifts daily with 70-90 workers per shift. The disruption is necessary for the final phase of the $1.5 billion Portal North Bridge replacement project.

articles.excerpt: Commuters should brace for major disruptions on rail lines serving New York. Starting February 15, NJ Transit and Amtrak will reduce train service by over 50 percent for a four-week period to connect the new $2.3 billion Portal North Bridge to the Northeast Corridor. More than 600 daily trains will be affected in the Newark-to-Secaucus corridor that feeds into Penn Station.

articles.title: Portal North Bridge Enters Final Phase of Construction as Work Begins to Put First Track into Service
articles.excerpt: Beginning February 13, 2026, Amtrak will transfer one track of rail service from the 115-year-old Portal Bridge in Kearny, NJ to the new Portal North Bridge over the Hackensack River. This Gateway Program milestone requires a multi-week reduction in Amtrak and NJ Transit service in New Jersey and the Northeast Corridor. Amtrak President Roger Harris called the cutover 'a whole new level of reliability on the Northeast Corridor.'

articles.title: 2026 will bring toll hikes, projects on NJ transportation front
articles.excerpt: The Garden State transportation universe that Gov.-elect Mikie Sherrill will inherit in 2026 is nothing short of busy. Big events such as the FIFA World Cup are nearing, and massive infrastructure projects are underway like the Port Authority bus terminal and Gateway rail tunnel projects. And the new Portal Bridge will open later in the year.

articles.title: Despite upgrades, delays will continue for NJ Transit, Amtrak riders
articles.excerpt: Commuting on the Northeast Corridor will likely get worse before it gets better. During the first 10 days of December, NJ Transit and Amtrak customers endured delays or cancellations on five of those days due to overhead wire issues, signal problems, an engine failure and problems caused by contractors working on the new Portal North Bridge.

articles.title: Northeast Corridor riders will face delays as work on this N.J. bridge continues
articles.excerpt: Commuters who depend on the busy Northeast Corridor line will learn next month how work to switch one track over to the new Portal North Bridge will affect rail service when it starts in February. The long-awaited change moves one track from from the current 115-year-old Portal swing bridge to the first of two tracks on the new $2.3 billion Portal North Bridge over the Hackensack River in Kearny....

Exact timetables are pending. Yahoo - The Portal North Bridge is a fixed‑span, 50‑foot‑high replacement that removes the need for bridge openings and addresses a major Northeast Corridor choke point...

articles.title: Cutover to new Portal Bridge could disrupt NJ Transit, Amtrak train service for 6 weeks
articles.excerpt: Significant schedule changes could upend rail service for NJ Transit and Amtrak customers in early 2026 so workers can get some of the final pieces in place to open the new Portal North Bridge next year, NorthJersey.com has learned. Some trains will likely need to be rerouted or canceled over what could be about six weeks.

articles.title: NJ Transit settles with fired engineer who raised issues about new Portal Bridge
articles.excerpt: A fired NJ Transit employee who raised concerns about construction of the new Portal North Bridge was paid a $450,000 settlement earlier this year. Mohammed Nasim was fired in October 2023 and said at the time in an exclusive interview with NorthJersey.com that it came as a “surprise” and was “a very unfair decision.”

articles.title: Amtrak Shares Portal North Bridge Progress
articles.excerpt: KEARNY, N.J. - Work progresses on the Portal North Bridge. Amtrak shared an update on LinkedIn of the Portal North Bridge project in Kearny, N.J. Over the last three weeks, crews have added 800 tons of ballast and installed 1,200 linear feet of track and ties. Amtrak thanked its partners at NJ Transit for their work between site visits. Below is a gallery of images, courtesy of Amtrak. Tags:...

articles.title: Op
articles.excerpt: Each week, my wife and I drop our son and daughter off at daycare, search for a parking space, and head (sometimes running) to our local station to ride a New Jersey Transit train toward New York City for work. Like countless other families across New Jersey, we are completely reliant on public transportation to make our livelihoods possible — and to deliver us back home in time to pick up our...

articles.title: Transit News: NJ Portal Bridge to Finish in 2026
articles.excerpt: A massive portal bridge spanning across the Hackensack River in Kearny is set to finish in mid 2026. The much-needed bridge was approved to replace its 114-year-old counterpart over the same river that has been the cause of many of the NJ Transit and Amtrak delays over the last decade. Amtrak CEO Stephen Gardner has stated that the bridge is roughly 80% of the way through construction. The...

articles.title: Portal bridge on track for mid
articles.excerpt: The massive three spans of the new Portal North Bridge have been lifted in place and are expected to be ready for trains next year, officials said Wednesday. “We believe the first set of tracks will be open by the middle of 2026,” NJ Transit CEO Kris Kolluri said during a tour of the worksite on the banks of the Hackensack River Wednesday. The new bridge replaces a problematic 114-year-old bridge...

articles.title: Portal North Bridge's Third Arch In Place
articles.excerpt: Amtrak and NJ TRANSIT highlight the delivery of the third and final arch for the Portal North Bridge. KEARNY, N.J. - Amtrak CEO Stephen Gardner and NJ TRANSIT President and CEO Kris Kolluri visited the Portal North Bridge to highlight the third arch's delivery. The third arch is the final of the bridge span to be delivered. RT&S reported on the delivery of the first arch in November 2024. These...

articles.title: Portal North Bridge's final arch put into place as construction continues

articles.title: Portal North Bridge
articles.excerpt: NJ TRANSIT and Amtrak are replacing the century-old Portal Bridge over the Hackensack River in New Jersey with a higher bridge that will not have to open and close for river traffic. The existing, century-old Portal Bridge was built by the Pennsylvania Railroad and entered revenue service in November 1910. The bridge carries more than 450 daily Amtrak and NJ TRANSIT trains and 200,000 daily...
